comment.author: 80428132@N00
comment._content: This image beautifully captures a moment.

comment.author: 69033322@N00
comment._content: 1)The awning where I've added a note in the photo appears to say Knox's Hats. According to this blog entry, Arnold Hatters aka Knox Hats started out in Times Square. There's a 2005 New York Times story included. So perhaps this photo is from the times Times Square area way back when -- where Broadway and 7th Avenue intersect.. 2)The lettering on the building (see another note in the photo) refers to the Garfield National Bank. According to an historic New York Times article, this bank was favored by Tammany Hall politicians. So again it appears that this photo is from Manhattan.

comment.author: 8256808@N02
comment._content: Looking at the hi-res version of this pic on the LOC site, there's a whole lot of text otherwise invisible on the Flickr photo. The cars have what appear to be signs with the last names of athletes--including Dukes, Donohue, Forhsaw, Erickson, Grumpelt, Gillis, Hellawell, Hebner, Hammond, Breed, Bowman, Rayner, Kiviat, and Kramer. (I've put notes on the photo detailing the barely-visible text.) Also, while it's a little blurry, there's a sign that appears to say "W 24 ST," which would make this NYC's Madison Square Park and environs. Maybe this was taken from the Flatiron Building?

comment.author: 8256808@N02
comment._content: Oh yeah. That building on the left has to be 200 Fifth Avenue a.k.a. the International Toy Center Building. So this is definitely around Madison Square Park.

comment.author: 27109792@N00
comment._content: Those are cable cars on the right. Though, I can't find a map of any NY cable car system

comment.author: 69033322@N00
comment._content: Good catch on the high res version of the photo, epicharmus, not to mention the teeny tiny street sign. I forgot about the high res version. Here's the link if anyone else is interested.

comment.author: 8256808@N02
comment._content: This here is Kevin Walsh's Forgotten NY page on trolley cars; this is one of the Lumière Brothers' short films taken at Union Square with lots of trolleys.

comment.author: 69033322@N00
comment._content: I've also added a note for the Von Lengerke and Detmold Sporting Goods per the high res version of the photo. United Cigar Stores Co., too.

comment.author: 8256808@N02
comment._content: Annin & Company--the manufacturers of the Wilson/Marshall banner--still exist!

comment.author: 69033322@N00
comment._content: Here's the exact same intersection (same clock, storefront look) from the New York Public Library's digital collection. Just click on the photo to go to the NYPL page. Here's a link to lots of vintage photos from the NYPL from the Madison Square Park area. Great stuff.

comment.author: 27109792@N00
comment._content: not to split hairs, but cable cars aren't the same as electric trolleys. You can tell in this picture by the center slot where the car grips cable, there isn't any overhead electricity. According to Joe Thompson's site this is the Broadway line of the Metropolitan Street Railway. www.cable-car-guy.com/html/ccnynj.html#msry

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: See www.flickr.com/photos/library_of_congress/2163157759/ for another picture of the same event and location, which shows "5th Ave" on a lamp-post. Garfield National Bank is visible in both. Its building was the corner of 23rd and Fifth, according to NYT in 1909. And, of course, Broadway intersects here too at the corner of Madison Square.

comment.author: 34427466731@N01
comment._content: This image has been used in the indicommons.org post: Flickring across the Library of Congress

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The 1912 Olympic games were held in Stockholm, Sweden, from late June to late July. This event in New York City, on August 24, must have been a "welcome home" ceremony, for recognition of returning American athletes, and a celebration of their achievements.

comment.author: 95323162@N00
comment._content: I wonder if Jim Thorpe was caught some where in this series.
